newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: FOCUS - Malaysian Hock Hua's Sabah unit acquired.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Malaysian Hock Hua's Sabah unit acquired.

text.p: Associates of Malaysian government economic adviser Daim Zainuddin said on Wednesday they were taking over small bank Hock Hua (Sabah) Bhd for 190 million ringgit ($75.7 million).
The move is seen by financial analysts as a precursor of bigger things for the tiny bank situated in Sabah state on Borneo island, including a possible merger with another bank.
Previously unknown private firm Langkah Bahagia Sdn Bhd announced it was buying a 51.8 percent stake in the bank and plans to raise the bank's shareholders' funds to one billion ringgit.

Langkah Bahagia will make a mandatory general takeover offer for the remaining shares of Hock Hua Sabah it does not already own. Malaysia British Assurance Bhd holds a roughly 12 percent stake in the bank.
The 12-branch bank was a subsidiary of listed Hock Hua Bank Bhd.

"We have received the approval of the minister of finance and (central) Bank Negara Malaysia to acquire 51.8 percent in Hock Hua Bank Sabah Bhd," Mohd Nasir Ali, director of Langkah Bahagia, said in a speech at a news conference.

He said Langkah aimed to increase the shareholders' funds of Hock Hua Sabah to one billion ringgit in order to attain "Tier-1" status under Malaysia's two tier banking system. Tier-1 banks operate in a more liberal regulatory environment.
Nasir said to boost the shareholders' funds, Langkah Bahagia may opt for cash or asset injections. "It could also go public," he said.
The bank reported net profit of 8.597 million ringgit in 1996, against 6.136 million the year before.
Nasir said Daim, an influential politician who is a trusted aide of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, is an interested party but has no management say.
"Tun (Daim) is an interested party in the deal. I am a nominee for a certain percentage of his shares," Nasir said. "Tun is just an investor," he added.
Analysts said 190 million ringgit was a fair price to pay for a banking licence, a rare commodity as the central bank has not issued any new licences in more than two decades.
"The deal's price is about right. It's a pretty good price to pay for a banking licence," said Chan Wee Lee, banking analyst at Jupiter Securities.
Analysts said the move to increase the bank's capital means that bigger things are afoot for Hock Hua Sabah, especially with Daim seen playing an important background role.
"I don't think that this is the end of the exercise. I think it will be merged with another bank," said Tan Pye Sen, analyst at Pesaka Jardine Fleming.

Questioned about the possible injection of Hock Hua Sabah into UCM Industrial Corp Bhd, of which Nasir is a director, he said that UCM, which has a stockbroking arm, was undergoing a restructuring exercise of its own. "For the time being, we are not going to (bring it) under UCM", Nasir said.
